subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] dictionary, script not working
msgSnippet: The dictionary, however it was produced does not use #34, the short o sound, which Read illustrated with the word O-x.  It should appear in words such as
messageBody:
The dictionary, however it was produced does not use #34, the short "o" sound, which Read illustrated with the word "O-x."  It should appear in words such as "hot," "pot", "hobby," "stocky," etc.  The long "A-h" sound (#32), instead, is used throughout this dictionary. Examples:  "father," "calm." "alarm."  This is a longer vowel and should not be mistaken for #34.

Paige

Ted Larson Freeman wrote:

Hi Paul,

Sorry to hear about the MS Word conversion.. .

I have no idea how this list was created. I see that the converter was uploaded by group member jeff_smith_8992. Jeff, are you out there??

Ted


On 10/11/07, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@iglou. com> wrote:

Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
> Hi Paul,
>
> I don't use Windows either, but if you unzip the file
> QsConverter_ 1_2_1.zip and look in the resulting directory you'll find
> the dictionary file QS_Dict_TextOnly. txt. I converted this into a file
> in Rich Text Format, available here:
>
> http://staff. washington. edu/freeman/ qs/qs_dict. rtf
> <http://staff. washington. edu/freeman/ qs/qs_dict. rtf>
>
> It's a big file, but I still find it usable as a reference by simply
> searching for words that I'm having difficulty transcribing. When I
> tried converting it to PDF format it was too large to be useful. I'd be
> happy to upload this file to the group website if others would like it
> to be there.
>
> Note that this file does not contain a single instance of QS letter #34
> ("On" in Jon Zuck's nomenclature) .
>

Thanks Ted,

That file helps a lot. Though, I opened it in Word, saved it as Unicode
text, and then spent about an hour wondering why I kept getting
corruption when I used it as a database for a script I wrote that
converts Traditional Orthogrpahy (TO) to QS. It ended up being the way
Word converted the file to text--don't ask me why. F*** Microsoft products.

Anyway, it is not in a plain text file, which I think is useful. Do you
know how this dictionary was generated? It seems it was generated
automatically with some type of script, because, for example, there are
multiple entries for "a." Also, from what I can tell so far, at least
some of the entrires differ from standard American pronounciation.

Paul
